Posts.Content: May 24, 2009 06:02AM - edited May 24, 2009 06:07AM by mom_of_2 I have had my port almost one year now. I am thankful I have it. My veins would not of held up. The procedure itself is done under twilight (light) anesthesia and you do not feel a thing. Procedure goes quickly and recovery is soreness. Most people you don't see any signs that they have a port. My sticks out so can be uncomfortable because I hit it or clothes rub against it...BUT still worth it. Cannot tell you how may times I have watched patients sit as the nurses struggle to get IV's going. I got a prescription for Lidocaine which I apply before my treatment to the top of the port then I cover with a Tegaderm. By the time the nurse access the port it is numb so I do not feel the needle.  You can do this!
Posts.Title: Does anyone have a port? aaronali12 GramE

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2009 11:01PM mom_of_2 wrote: I pulled the buff right-side out and but not tight then from the outside rolled knot to one end. When I started rolling from outside the knot was still inside out. Hope this makes sense. I guess it was a lot of practice since I never wore the wig I bought.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2009 04:57AM mom_of_2 wrote: I did the pirate twist where you start with the buff inside out and arms crossed over inside and pulled right-side out. Sometimes I felt like there wasn't enough coverage but I gently pulled sides near knot and covered more of my head. I also learned to tuck the tail up under the knot which I personally liked better. Hope this helped...they really are great once you get the hang of them. Kris

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 06:14AM mom_of_2 wrote: I am 6 weeks out from "the tomorrow" you are facing and I feel for you. Like Sherry said...keep yourself busy. I had lunch with a good friend on the way to pre-op testing and kept my husband on the phone until the nurse called my name. I cried in the waiting room but was ok once thing were underway. Sleep the night before was thanks to Ambiem CR and I was allowed to take Ativan the morning of surgery. In the morning, I just went through the motions getting to hospital. Hugs were really tough then I got drugs. Apparently, I was the bell of the ball once I got meds! Recovery has been much better than I would have ever expected and new girls are so perky. I do not regret my decision for one second and would do it all again.  You can do this...you will fight...you will win. You are in my thoughts...Kris

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2009 06:26AM mom_of_2 wrote: I had cording from dissection sight...down arm...inside of elbow...into wrist. I went to lymphedema therapist who helped me workout my arm. In the beginning I couldn't raise arm above my shoulders. By the end I got back full range of motion and the cording broke up. It was hard to be patient but in the end it all worked out. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2009 09:29AM - edited Mar 31, 2009 09:34AM by mom_of_2 Ruth, I am so sorry for your diagnosis. I do believe you can beat this and watch your daughter grow-up. I was diagnosed on June 2, 2008 (age 40) with right sided invasive ductal carcinoma and DCIS. I underwent 20 weeks of chemo/herceptin, bi lateral mastectomy, reconstruction and now continuing herceptin until June 16, 2009. I began Tamoxifan for 5 years on December 30th with no side effects. I have 2 teenagers and I was consumed with the "what ifs" of not seeing them grow-up. I am in a much better place now as treatment has been successful. I have all the faith in the world that you will thrive. Surgical procedure is a personal choice. For me...bi lateral was the only thing I would consider and have absolutely no regrets! Left side was healthy but mastectomy has eased my worry. Surgery was not nearly as hard as expected. Recovery was a good 6 weeks. Hardest part for me was asking for help!!! Please let me know how you are doing. All the best, Kris

No worries about them slipping off either. I swear by them! Good Luck

Posts.Content: May 15, 2009 09:31AM mom_of_2 wrote: I'm sitting here with plastic wrap covering my head and the homemade hot oil/rosemary treatment. Feels great and is suppose to promote hair growth! If it washes out well then I think I'll be hooked! Although...the aroma is making me want to open a good bottle of red wine and have some parmesan and french bread! I had my color done yesterday and bought the DevaCare No Poo and One Conditioner. Product is made by DevaCurl for color treated hair. Sulfate free and helps to tame the wild curl beast! Hair stylist told me curly hair only needs to be washed twice per week but scalp massaged in shower under hot water and then lightly conditioned daily. Another trick is to use a t-shirt to get water out of hair instead of a towel which can cause breakage and frizz in curly hair. Biggest rule is do not touch while its drying. If you just let it air dry there is no frizz to speak of. I had no idea curly hair had so many rules!

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 02:16PM mom_of_2 wrote: So very sorry. There is going to be so much info thrown at you in next fews weeks so brace yourself. I had a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction last December. Recovery is a good 6-8 weeks. The most difficult part was trying to sit-up in bed and dealing with the drains. A lot of women just sleep in recliners. I didn't have that option. My kids were older 14 and 17 so they were able to help. Of course reaching and lifting are a no no. Have they done biopsies yet? Once you get pathology they will be able to come up with a treatment plan. You need to know your ER, PR, HER2 status. I had chemo first to shrink tumor but elected for mastectomy anyway. Some doctors prefer surgery first. Depends on your team and what you want. Please know you are not alone. We have all been right where you are and we want to help you through this nightmare. All the best Kris
Posts.Title: just diagnosed...can't believe it!!! nanadada nanadada

Posts.Content: mom_of_2 wrote: Just wondering what the board thinks...here is my situation: Diagnosed 40, no family history, stage IIb, 2.8 IDC & DCIS, grade II, ER+ PR+ HER2+, SNB 1/23, neo chemo x 20wks, bi lat mast w/ TE, 52 wks herceptin and tamox. Medical oncology says no rads...treatment already very aggressive and benefits don't outweigh risks. Also added had mastectomy been performed prior to chemo they wouldn't offer rads. Surgical oncology and radiation oncology say its grey area and can go either way. Risks however of rads are high due to existing lymphodema.   I have talked myself in circles about this so any info is greatly appreciated. Thanks, Kris  mom_of_2 Dx 6/2/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 1/23 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

I had consult with very aggressive Assistant Professor of Radiation Oncology before surgery and at first she said maybe but after taking case to tumor board said no. MD Anderson doc agrees with my rads oncologist pre mast but questions now post mastectomy. ALL I WANT IS TO DO THE RIGHT THING A GIVE MYSELF THE LOWEST POSSIBLE RECURRENCE %!

Posts.Content: May 6, 2009 11:02PM mom_of_2 wrote: Nicole... Did I read on another thread where you have a 14 yr old sibling? Wanted to let you know that my son was 13 and my daughter 17 when I was diagnosed. It hasn't been easy and somedays were nightmares but my kids have been through every step with me (surgery, chemo, hair loss, more surgery, more surgery etc). We talked every day...there were no secrets. Now I can see the relief in their faces and a new found lightness in their daily walks. My daughter is graduating in 2 weeks and has more to be thankful for than ever. We beat this and plan a long and happy life together. Some days are going to be really hard for you and your family...but hang in there...there is a very bright light at the end of this journey!
Posts.Title: For my Mom aka Superwoman Nicole_Bronx Nicole_Bronx

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 04:35PM - edited Feb 11, 2009 04:36PM by mom_of_2 Myriad is the only lab in the US that runs BRCA testing according to my doctors. If insurance denies - YOU MUST APPEAL! In my case there was no family history or reason for test other than my diagnosis. My insurance was pre-certified but genetic testing facility said we should fight if denied and they help with letters and clinical. I had 3 gene marker tested ($400) first and since it was negative went ahead with comprehensive reading ($2725). Another thing my genetic counselor told me is on the off chance insurance won't pay...Myriad cuts deals for payment and should talk to you prior to running test. Good Luck
Posts.Title: BRCA testing/costs/MYRIAD lab samiam40 SelenaRG

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 06:36PM mom_of_2 wrote: Hate to tell you ladies but my SNB was far worse than my bilateral mastectomy :( My surgical oncologist said it can take up to 18 months to heal. I had mine June 2008 (almost 17 months ago) and I am just now getting back full range of motion. Still have numbness and occasional sharp pain.
Posts.Title: pain after sentinel lymphnode biopsy mimi1964 Kushie

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 01:19AM mom_of_2 wrote: I spent 2 nights at the hospital and recovery at home was a good couple of weeks +. When I got home I was able to shower and empty my drains by myself but needed help in and out of bed etc. My kids 17 and 14 were a big help but I counted on family and friends as to not have the kids feel responsible for me. I am a month out now and finally able to reach into cabinets by myself and do some light cooking. I definitely recommend help...line up anyone who has offered. It was difficult but when friends offer to bring dinner over when I was diagnosed in June...I ask them to wait until December/January after surgery. Everyone was happy to help and the company was nice. Plus I felt like it gave my family a break. Good luck
Posts.Title: How Long in Hospital after Bi-Later with Reconstruction? Mocity mom_of_2

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2009 08:02PM mom_of_2 wrote: My daughter was a rising senior last summer when I was diagnosed. We had just dropped her off for 6 weeks of intensive music study. We drove to see her, so I could tell her in person. I knew she wasn't alone but I worried about her too much to tell her over the phone. I think it was actually good for her to be away in the beginning. We talked/texted/emailed daily but it didn't seem like reality to her. We had one long weekend together during the summer and it was hard for her to see me bald and lacking energy but she rose to the occasion. She came home ready to start her senior year and be here for me. We have talked a lot about what it was like for her when I was diagnosed and she agrees being away was good in many ways even though it was very difficult for both of us. Personally my daughter would have never forgiven me if I had kept this from her for any reason. Good Luck and Be Strong...she can handle this!
Posts.Title: When to tell daughter away in college Eliza2009 murphmort

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 06:40PM mom_of_2 wrote: Ladies...My family claims I have become obsessed but ever since my bilateral in December I have been cleaning the chemicals out of my house. There is a great website cosmeticdatabase.com which is a skin deep cosmetic safety review. Be prepared to be sucked in and tempted to throw out everything in your house from mascara to shave cream. I have found some products we really love and some that I would not buy again. I feel much better just knowing I am in control of how many chemicals I am putting on my body every day. Just a note for those that are ER+. I found out after buying a large bottle of all natural lavender website safe soap...lavender and tea tree can mimic estrogen. Since the skin actually absorbs estrogen product at a higher percent than if it is taken orally...I avoid it like the plague!

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2009 08:20AM mom_of_2 wrote: Practical Ways to Keep Your House Clean and Safe from Parenting Bookmark: Homemade Remedies and Cleaners: Air Freshener: To absorb odors, place bowls of vinegar, or baking soda around the house. Be sure to keep them out of reach of children and pets! To make the air more fragrant, use essential oils or boiled herbs. To make herbs, simply choose any herb or spice the smell of which you enjoy and boil it in water for a few minutes until the heat causes it to release its aroma. Let it cool a little and put it out in a bowl. You can also add salt to discourage the growth of fungus. Drain Cleaner: Use hair and food traps to keep the drain from getting clogged. If it does become clogged, try the following recipe. First, pour about 1/2 cup of baking soda down the sink. Then add at least a cup of vinegar. It will start to fizz. Put the cover over the drain. Finish up by rinsing the drain with a mixture of boiling salt water. You might have to repeat the procedure. Toilet Bowl Cleaner: Sprinkle baking soda around the inside of the toilet bowl and then clean with a toilet brush. Also try letting white vinegar sit for a few minutes in the bowl before cleaning with toilet brush.  Oven Cleaner: Make a paste of baking soda and water. First wipe away any residual grease. Then scrap off burnt spots with scouring brush or steel wool. Finally, apply paste and scrub. Laundry Detergent: By adding baking soda, you can reduce the amount of commercial detergent you use substantially. If you're using liquid detergent, add about 1/2 cup of baking soda at the beginning of the wash. If you are using powdered detergent, add 1/2 cup baking soda during rinse cycle. Baking soda softens the water, thus increasing the potency of your detergent. When buying commercial detergent, it is better to use biodegradable, less toxic, phosphate free brand. Window Cleaner: Put 3 Tablespoons vinegar per quart of water into spray bottle. Automatic Dishwashing Detergent:  As you pile dishes in the sink, sprinkle with baking soda. Then, later when you put them in the dishwasher you can use a lot less commercial detergent. It's the same basic idea as with the laundry detergent. Carpet Cleaner: To absorb big spills, spread cornmeal all over the spill. Wait about 15 minutes, then vacuum it up. For stains, put 1/4 cup biodegradable liquid soap with 1/3 cup water into blender to make foam. Put the foam on the stain and rub. Finish up with a splash of vinegar. Kitchen Cleanser: Just use baking soda on non-scratch surfaces, and a vinegar water mixture on other surfaces. Tub and Tile Cleaner: Mix 1 and 2/3 cup baking soda, 1/2 cup liquid soap, 1/2 cup water and finally 2 tablespoons vinegar (if you add the vinegar too early it will react with the baking soda). Then apply, wipe and scrub. Shoe Polish: Use a little olive oil. Brass and Copper Cleaner: Cut a lemon in half, sprinkle it with salt and rub the lemon on whatever needs to be polished. Buff with cloth to remove excess lemon juice. Silver Polish: Put a sheet of aluminum foil into plastic of glass bowl. Sprinkle the foil with salt and baking soda, then fill the bowl with warm water. Just soak your silver in the bowl and the tarnish will migrate to the foil. Finally, dry and buff. Fragrance: If you are not chemically sensitive or allergic, essential plant oils can be a pleasing addition to homemade cleaners. A few drops can enhance our perception of cleanliness. Commerical Cleaners and Disinfectants If you do not feel like making your own cleaners, there are a number of less toxic alternatives which can be found at organic and natural grocery stores, co-ops and many larger conventional stores as well. Examples include: Ecover, Earth's Best, Seventh Generation, Earthrite, Earth Friendly, Bio Clean, Life Tree and Dr. Bronner's. Organic and biodegradable products are generally the safest. Natural products tend to be the next safest and conventional cleaners and disinfectants are the least safe.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2009 03:02PM mom_of_2 wrote: Thank you ladies...I have just gotten final word and entire team says no rads. This 1-3 nodes thing is such a grey area and all three oncologist researched and discussed to come to their conclusion. I am at peace with the decision. Good news is...we can move forward with implant swap! March 11 is my day! Thank you again...your support has meant the world to me! Kris
Posts.Title: RADS VS. NO RADS mom_of_2 Alyad

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2009 05:28PM mom_of_2 wrote: I referred to my scars as my FRANKENBOOBS! I thought the same thing as far as jagged incisions. I was expecting precision and straight lines. BUT now 10 months post mastecomy I am thrilled with end result. I would have never believed that scars could look so good given time to heal. After I had tattooing done scars are barely visible and I take my shirt off in the locker room again ! I would be happy to email you a pic if you send me a PM with your address. All the best...Kris
Posts.Title: What to Expect Mastectomy Scars to Look like??? ameron Erica

Posts.Content: May 5, 2009 03:13PM - edited May 5, 2009 03:14PM by mom_of_2 Hi Nicole... If it make you feel any better about things...I saw my medical oncologist today and I was drilling her about my prognosis. She said I have such a small chance of recurrence that she is not worried. I have 2 more Herceptin infusions and she said I should enjoy my life. They aren't setting me free...I will have follow-ups every 3 months and am taking Tamoxifen but things look good. 11 months ago when I was diagnosed...IDC, DCIS, ER+, PR+, HER2+, BRAC- I couldn't imagine being so healthy today. Herceptin is an amazing drug and should really help your moms %. Your mom has a long road but she will be fine. I have all the faith in the world that she will beat this. My oncologist words "breast cancer is no longer a death sentence".
Posts.Title: For my Mom aka Superwoman Nicole_Bronx Nicole_Bronx
